III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Policy and procedures
Title
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12403
Section • (1) An agency shall provide a copy of the policies and
Description procedures to the foster parents of a home where the
agency places a child.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation A foster youth was provided psychotropic medication without
parental consent.
Investigation Parent 1 was contacted on April 18, 2024, by way of phone. A
discussion was held surrounding a time to interview her regarding
the allegations. She stated a good time for her would be April 22,
2024. She was very pleased she was contacted to discuss Youth
A’s medical care. The investigation was initiated and concluded
with a date for a more comprehensive interview scheduled for
April 22, 2024, at 1:00pm per her request.
Chief Administrator was contacted by email on April 18, 2024,
to discuss the allegations. He responded and a date was set for
video conference on April 25, 2024, at 10:45am.
Parent 1 was interviewed by telephone on April 22, 2024. She
stated Youth A was forced to take medication for attention deficit
hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) without her consent. She stated
the foster parent also neglected to inform the MDHHS Department
about administering the medication. Parent 1 said the foster
parent took Youth A to their family physician who prescribed the
medication and Youth A was not tested prior to taking the
medication. She stated she does not agree with Youth A taking
medications and Youth A has never been tested for having ADHD.
Parent 1 stated she received information that Youth A was taking
2

medication at a parenting time meeting and Youth A informed her
he was taking crushed medication and that it was placed in his
applesauce.
Parent 1 said she wanted to do her own investigation, so she
reached out to Youth A’s teacher to find out his behaviors in her
classroom. She said the teacher reported Youth A does
absolutely fantastic at school. She said the teacher reported
Youth A always comes to class with a smile on his face and a
positive attitude and he has no problems making friends. Parent 1
sent the teacher email dated January 24, 2024, to this Consultant
for verification.
Interview with the Chief Administrator (CA) on April 25, 2024,
by video conference. The CA explained he had recently been
promoted to the CA position and he knew of the case, but not
specific details. He invited the Foster Care Program Manager and
another DHHS Supervisor. Both individuals were newly promoted
to their positions and were not able to provide any detailed
information regarding the allegation. He referred me to the
assigned Foster Care Worker and her Supervisor and provided
contact information for each of them.
Interview with the assigned Foster Care Worker (FCW) by
video conference on April 26, 2024. She reported she was
assigned to Youth A and his sibling case since opening on March
1st, 2023. She said she visits Youth A in his foster care
placement once a month. She said she discusses medical issues
and upcoming appointments with Foster Parent 1 and Foster
Parent 2. She stated on one of the home visits, Foster Parent 1
mentioned Youth A was showing signs of ADHD, not focusing,
had little attention span and fetal alcohol syndrome. She said the
Foster Parent 1 scheduled a psychosocial assessment for Youth
A. FCW stated Youth A had a trauma assessment coming up so
she informed Foster Parent 1 she could keep the psychosocial
assessment scheduled because the department supports
implementing any and all services that are in the best interest of
the child. FCW stated she informed Parent 1 of the scheduled
psychosocial assessment by way of screenshots as well as Youth
A’s trauma assessment that was ordered by the courts. FCW
stated Youth A’s psychosocial assessment diagnosis of ADHD
was sent to Community Mental Health (CMH) where his trauma
assessment was scheduled. She said (CMH) kept Youth A’s
diagnosis that originally came from the psychosocial assessment.
3

FCW stated Foster Parent 1 had given Youth A allergy and cold
medicine previously when he was not feeling well. She stated in a
parenting visit that took place on November 27, 2023, Parent 1
notice Youth A had a cough and a stuffy nose. Parent 1 asked
Youth A what medications he was taking for his cold. FCW stated
Youth A responded by stating he was taking a pill that is put in his
applesauce. FCW stated Parent 1 continued to question Youth A
about the medication, and she intervened and reminded Parent 1
that Youth A was only five years old and does not know what kind
of medicine he is taking. FCW stated she shared with Parent 1
that it is not uncommon for children to have pills or vitamins
crushed in applesauce or yogurt to get them to take their
medication. She said she informed Parent 1 that she (FCW)
would do a follow up with Foster Parent 1.
FCW stated Parent 1 texted Foster Parent 1 during the parenting
visit and asked what type of pill she was giving Youth A that had
to be crushed and placed in his applesauce. FCW said Foster
Parent 1 told Parent 1 to address the issue with Youth A’s FCW.
FCW stated this is when she learned Foster Parent 1 was giving
Youth A medicine for ADHD. FCW said she had Foster Parent 1
send her a copy of the medications that Youth A was taking. She
said this was the first time she had seen the medication list that
Youth A was taking, and the Department was not aware of this
medication, nor did Parent 1 give her consent for Youth A to take
the medication. She said both the Department and Parent 1
learned that Youth A was taking medication for ADHD at the same
time. FCW said she provided the list of medications, the CMH
form and Youth A’s ADHD diagnosis to Parent 1. FCW stated
anytime Youth A has any type of appointments she informs Parent
1 when she receives notifications of any appointments. FCW said
Parent 1 begin to read the information out loud, became upset and
stated she did not agree with Youth A receiving the medication.
FCW said she took immediate action and filed a 3200 on Foster
Parent 1.
FCW stated she informed Foster Parent 1 to stop providing Youth
A with the medication immediately. She said there were 30 pills
and Youth A had taken four and 26 of them were left in the bottle.
FCW stated Youth A was taking the psychotropic medication
Concerti/methylphenidate.
Foster Parents 1 and 2 were interviewed on 7/1/2024. Both
Foster Parent 1 and Foster Parent 2 agreed that giving the
psychotropic medication to Youth A without getting the consent
from the caseworker and parent was their fault and that they take
4

full responsibility. Both admitted they were aware of the agency
policies and procedures, and they had signed and dated the
policies and procedures beforehand. Foster Parent 2 added when
the caseworker informed them to stop giving Youth A the pills,
they discontinued immediately. He said it was evidence when the
caseworker came out to their home and received 26 pills where 4
pills were administered to Youth A before they were told to
discontinue providing the pills to Youth A. Both reported they were
never given permission to start Youth A on psychotropic
medication. Both stated they know their mistake; they have a
safety plan in place, and they are following it.
Documents reviewed:
• Psychosocial assessment dated September 19, 2023,
provided Youth A with a diagnosis of ADHD (attention
deficit hyperactivity disorder), combined type F90.2.
Diagnosis Rationale states Youth A meets diagnostic
criteria for attention deficit/hyperactivity disorder, combined
type. Foster Parent 1 reported to the tester that Youth A
lacks attention to detail and makes frequent mistakes, he is
inattentive with tasks, seems to ignore people speaking
directly to him, and fails to complete tasks or instructions.
Youth A is disorganized, misplaces possessions related to
tasks and is often distracted. Foster Parent 1 reported to
the tester that Youth A is restless, leaves his seat and runs
or climbs when it is not appropriate. Youth A talks
energetically and excessively, answers questions before
they are finished and interrupts others when talking.
• Per MiSACWIS; a DHHS investigation was opened on the
foster parent’s home on November 28, 2023, by the
assigned agency. The allegation was Foster Parent 1 took
Youth A to the doctor and pretended to be his mother so
she could put Youth A on ADHD medication. Once she
obtained the medication, Foster Parent 1 began crushing
the medication up and putting the medication into Youth A’s
apple sauce. Foster Parent 1 was in violation with CPA
rule 400.9412 (1) Medical and dental care and 400.9403 (1)
(a) Foster parent duties. The DHHS report
recommendation was a corrective action plan which was
signed and dated by Foster Parent 1 and Foster Parent 2
on December 7, 2023, along with a safety plan that was
signed and dated by the foster parents on November 30,
2023.
5

• Per CWLM record, agency policies and procedures; foster
parent agency agreement, states the foster parent shall
read and demonstrate an understanding of foster home
licensing rules, and state and agencies policies and
procedures. This documented was signed by both foster
parents on November 28, 2023.
• Per documentation in CWLM, the Foster Parent 1 and
Foster Parent 2 were provided all of the agency policies
and procedures. All policies and procedures were signed
and dated by Foster Parent 1 and Foster Parent 2 where
Youth A was placed. It is noted that they have been
licensed since January 9, 2021 with Bethany Christian
Services – Holland. Foster Parent 1 and Foster Parent 2
were aware and have signed all of the agency policies and
procedures.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance. It is true that Foster Parent 1
provided medication to Youth A without Parent 1’s consent. It is
true that Foster Parent 1 and Foster Parent 2 did not inform the
Department, FCW nor Bethany Christian Services - Holland that
they had taken Youth A to Foster Parent 1’s pediatrician and
received medication for ADHD and began administrating the
medication to Youth A in applesauce. Foster Parent 1 and Foster
Parent 2 did not inform the Department that she took Youth A to
her pediatrician for ADHD medication, nor did Foster Parent 1 and
Foster Parent 2 receive consent from Parent 1 regarding her
approval for this medication to be administered. However, the
assigned agency provided Foster Parent 1 and Foster Parent 2
with all of the agency’s policies and procedures as required which
was signed and dated by the foster parents upon being licensed
and Youth A being placed in the home.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
6

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
